stories.text:
I am an IT Specialist/Front-end developer looking to get work abroad. The job search has been unsatisfactory so far, and I sense that employers might be looking for cheaper alternatives available locally instead of sponsoring a visa or taking on the risk of foreign workers. Despite my experience, how can I best indicate that I can take less salary, provide a higher ROI for them?

I'd appreciate any advice. Thanks
stories.title: How do I indicate willingness to take less salary when taking jobs overseas?
We are starting our operations in the EU – Estonia – [Matheus Bona OÜ]

stories.text:
Almost everyone I know keeps a list of (easily forgettable) command line snippets somewhere. I can't imagine that HN folks would be any different :)

So that said, could I please see your cheatsheet?

I'll go first: https://github.com/fastily/cheatsheet
stories.title: Ask HN: Can I see your cheatsheet?
Henry Ford Would Deal with Today’s Supply Chain Upheaval

stories.text:
I am the founder of this database product. A fundamental curiosity in my heart is, after tens years of development, can the bottom layer of the common-users-accessible database still develop?

JoinBase, is my initial answer to this question.

1. For the first time, it proposes the evolution of the database from the user's point of view.

New tech concepts such as cloud navtive, or HTAP or datalake are no longer encouraged to be consumed. What users want may be just a easy-to-use, efficient data tool that fits.

2. For the first time, it well supports three DB payload types in a single engine of a free industrial-grade database: TP single row transcation write, TP and AP read.

If you don't need complex transcation, it can meet almost of your needs in the domain.

3. For the first time, it is so fast that for most businesses, it is no longer necessary to use a distributed database for their data needs.

Any suggestions, questions and comments are welcome. I answer online.
stories.title: Show HN: JoinBase – Creates an Unprecedented Database for IoT Era
Enjoy Digital Ownership and Public Libraries While You Still Can
